author: sky.cactus
content: I believe everything is done with unsigned integers, so there is no sign.

author: chfast
content: This is by analogy to real number where the curve is symmetric by X axis. The signature gives you x coordinate and therefore two matching points on the curve (one with positive and one with negative y coordinate). So you need additional 1 bit information to select one of these points.

author: m.kalinin
content: In field arithmetics you have a notion of `-a` (inverse element) where `a + (-a) = 0 (identity element)`. `{0, 1}` represents a fact of whether it's `y` or `-y` but I guess for field arithmetics it's the same as parity

author: m.kalinin
content: Though, I am not sure where "parity" term is coming from in this context

author: chfast
content:
Ha! It looks you can check the least significant bit (I'd call it "parity") or check if point is `< p/2` ("sign"?). I believe we are using the second method so calling it "parity" instead of "sign" may be confusing.
https://crypto.stackexchange.com/questions/29429/determine-if-a-public-key-point-y-is-negative-or-positive-odd-or-even

author: m.kalinin
content: Ah, so, it's a parity of least significant bit

author: m.kalinin
content: So, there are two candidates for `y` and the parity bit shows the parity of the least significant bit of the right canidate
